content.question: Researchers collected two different samples, X and Y, of temperatures, in degrees Celsius, of the habitat for Florida scrub lizards. The confidence interval <math alttext="36 plus or minus 1.66" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>36</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>1.66</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> was constructed from sample X, and the confidence interval <math alttext="36 plus or minus 1.08" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>36</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>1.08</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> was constructed from sample Y. Assume both samples had the same standard deviation. Which of the following statements could explain why the width of the confidence interval constructed from X is greater than the width of the confidence interval constructed from Y?

choices.label: The sample size of X is greater than the sample size of Y, and the confidence level is the same for both intervals.

The sample size of X is greater than the sample size of Y, and the confidence level used for the interval constructed from X is less than the confidence level used for the interval constructed from Y.
The sample size is the same for X and Y, and the confidence level used for the interval constructed from X is less than the confidence level used for the interval constructed from Y.
The sample size is the same for X and Y, and the confidence level is the same for both intervals.
The sample size is the same for X and Y, and the confidence level used for the interval constructed from X is greater than the confidence level used for the interval constructed from Y.

content.answer: The sample size is the same for X and Y, and the confidence level used for the interval constructed from X is greater than the confidence level used for the interval constructed from Y.
